tossups.question: One figure with this surname introduced an unpopular “Quota System” of drafting sailors into the Royal Navy, while another established a reputation for honesty as Paymaster of the Forces during the “Broad Bottom” ministry. That figure with this surname teamed up with the Duke of Newcastle to form a ministry which saw the capture of Guadeloupe and victories at the battle of Quiberon Bay and Lagos during an “Annus Mirabilis”. A prime minister with this surname introduced Britain’s first modern income tax and resigned over the issue of (*) Catholic Emancipation. The ministry of that Prime Minister saw the United Irishmen Revolt, the British invasion of Haiti, and the French Revolution. For 10 points, which surname was shared by the political leader of Britain during the Seven Years’ War and the Whig Prime Minister of Britain from 1783 to 1801?
tossups.answer: Pitt (accept William Pitt the Elder or William Pitt the Younger; accept the 1st Earl of Chatham)

tossups.question: This ruler’s construction of the fortifications of Derbent was later attributed to Alexander the Great by some Arabic sources. The scholar Borzuya first translated the Panchatantra into Pahlavi during this man’s reign. This ruler supposedly created a “human garden” after burying followers of Mazdak with their feet in the air. It didn’t become a center of learning, but a city founded by this ruler was built as an exact replica, even down to the mulberry tree outside of a resident’s house, of a different conquered city that he called (*) “Better than” that conquered city. This ruler created four military districts for his domain, each defended by an army led by a spāhbed. This ruler was the first to take the Byzantine garrison town of Dara. After only eight years, this ruler broke an “Eternal Peace” with Justinian. For 10 points, identify this Sassanid ruler of the middle 6th century CE.
tossups.answer: Khosrau I (accept Khosrau the Just or Anushiravān the Just; accept Chosroes, Khosrow, Khusrau, or Kisrā in place of “Khosrau”)

tossups.question: Two answers required A commander from one of these powers complained of the other, "Are your seamen to fill your casks with wine rather than powder?" when that side couldn’t supply enough gunpowder during a joint siege. The first official diplomatic contact between these two powers was established by John Frangipani. Gabriel de Luetz was an ambassador from one of these two powers who advised the other in its siege of Van. To [emphasize] counteract the alliance between these two powers, two embassies to (*) Rudolf II were led by the Sherley brothers. The imprisonment of a monarch of one of these powers after the Battle of Pavia was a factor in the invasion of Hungary by the other, leading to the Battle of Mohács [MO-hahtch]. For 10 points, name these two powers who controversially allied under Suleiman the Magnificent and Francis I against the Habsburgs.
tossups.answer: Ottoman Empire and France (both parts required; prompt on partial answer)

tossups.question: Hosea Stout led the “whittling and whistling brigade”, a security force in this city, which deterred crime by doing the two title actions near suspicious-looking strangers. A “university” in this city was headed by John C. Bennett before he was stripped of his positions for adultery. A newspaper called [this city’s] Expositor published only a single issue because it was shut down for criticizing this city’s mayor. A military force named for this city was joined by 200 Paiute soldiers in its attack on the (*) Baker-Fancher party. Named after a Hebrew word meaning “they are beautiful”, this city’s most famous residents moved there after they were exiled by Missouri Executive Order 44. The residence of most of the Mormon community just before moving to Utah, for 10 points, name this city in western Illinois.

Archaeologist Hormuzd Rassam was among the hostages taken by a ruler of this country after his request for British aid was ignored. The Gideon Force aided native Arbegnoch forces to expel a foreign occupation of this country. A ruler of this country attempted to use a cannon named “Sebastopol” in the defense of a fortress at Amba Mariam, but it was too large to drag up the hill to the fort. Members of the Bloomsbury Group (*) pranked the Royal Navy by pretending to be part of this country’s royal family to tour the HMS Dreadnought. The organization AFROMET seeks the return of 468 artifacts stolen from this country by the British after the Battle of Magdala, including nine replicas of the Tablets of Law called tabots; the loss in that battle led Emperor Tewodros II to kill himself. For 10 points, name this country in East Africa, which received British aid in its resistance against Italian occupation.

A royal monopoly over this good was briefly interrupted as fifteen captaincies were given to private donataries to settle the coast where it was acquired. A virtual monopoly over this good, which previously competed with a transitory system dominated by truchements, was obtained after the destruction of a colony populated by both Catholics and Huguenots called France Antarctique. The discovery of a large source of one kind of this good in 1500 began the shift of global commerce from the Indian Ocean to the Atlantic and gave Europe an alternative to the Asian (*) sappan- variety. The first tightly-controlled feitorias in the New World were set up to trade for this good. A variety of this good was exported to Europe after trading with the Tupinamba people, and unusually was used to produce a red dye used for textiles like velvet. For 10 points, identify this commodity which gave Brazil its name and was, along with fur, the chief good exported from the Canadian hinterland.

It’s not Hawaii, but a large effort to consolidate landholdings in this kingdom was ironically called the Great Partition. Religious freedom in this kingdom was granted to immigrants and foreigners in 1781 and Jews in 1782, despite citizens being unable to publicly practice any form of Christianity other than the state church at the time; those restrictions emerged to curb the influence of radical Pietist groups like the Gray Robes. A ruler of this kingdom launched a successful coup in 1772 against his own parliament, effectively ending the power of the (*) Francophilic Hats and the Russophilic Caps. A tour around the Gulf of Bothnia by a resident of this kingdom helped him develop a system most famously laid out in Systema Naturae. For 10 points, identify this kingdom whose Royal Academy of Sciences was founded in part by Carl Linnaeus.

One text describes a region on this body of water as a paradise made lush by water divinely brought up out of the ground and where “the raven croaks not/ the lion does not kill”. Failaka Island was an important trading hub at the northern end of this body of water. Strabo describes the residents of Gerrha, believed to be on or near this body of water, as living in houses made of salt. Steffen Laursen has proposed that a system of symbols found in what is believed to be the (*) Dilmun culture on this body of water developed from trade with the Indus Valley. Foreign traders, such as from Meluhha and the aforementioned Dilmun, passing through this body of water before traveling upriver to his capital was a matter of pride for Sargon the Great. For 10 points, what is this body of water that the Tigris and Euphrates rivers flow into?

George Holt published an “Untold History” of one variety of this foodstuff in 2014. A version of this foodstuff that originated in the early 1980s features ingredients like pork bone and luósī [LOO-oh-sih] snail-based stock. The “fried sauce” variety of this foodstuff is served cold with vegetables such as sliced cucumbers and radishes, and another variety is made with kansui, or alkaline mineral water, and a production process for that variety was developed in 1958 by (*) Momofuku Ando. A popular variety of this foodstuff made with beef is named for this city of Lánzhōu [lahn-joh]. One variety of this foodstuff was introduced in the 1930s by the Prime Minister Phibun [pea-boon] to promote nationalism in his country, and that version of this foodstuff is served with scrambled egg, bean sprouts, and crushed peanuts. For 10 points, name this foodstuff whose varieties include Pad Thai and Ramen.
tossups.answer: Noodles (accept Instant Noodles, Ramen, luósī fěn, zhájiàng miàn, niúròu miàn, or Pad Thai)

tossups.question: In one story, a fictional ruler of this place joins a Muslim siege of Constantinople with gold-armored soldiers and 500 griffins. It’s not in Africa or the Middle East, but this place was once thought to be bordered by a “Red Sea”. Mutineer Fortún Ximénez (“she”-“MAIN”-ayth) may have been the first to apply the modern name of this place to actual land. The writings of Francis Pretty provided the basis for a forgery perpetrated by the E Clampus Vitus fraternity regarding the history of this place. This place is ruled by Queen Calafia and inhabited by only women in the book (*) The Adventures of Esplandián. A map created by Eusebio Kino contributed to the end of the belief that this place was an island. The fame of the mineral wealth of this place led to it to be the first [emphasize] overseas area to be known in China as “Gold Mountain”. For 10 points, identify this place, now two Mexican states and one American state home to Los Angeles.
tossups.answer: California (accept Baja California; antiprompt on New Albion)

tossups.question: Descriptive answer acceptable Weriyeng and fanur were two approaches to how this process was carried out. Earth ovens and stone flakes found on Enderby Island make it a confirmed boundary for the extent of this process. An early 20th century scholar depicted one stage of this process as an octopus, which occurred after an approximately 1,400 year “long pause”. The earliest phases of this process can be tracked through the distribution of the Lapita culture. In the 1970’s, a resident of Satawal, (*) Mau Piailug, helped revive a set of skills used in this process, which were only believed to have been known by six people. The means by which this process occurred were tested through the voyages of the Hōkūleʻa. For 10 points, name this process through which places like Rapa Nui and New Zealand came to be first inhabited.
tossups.answer: settlement of the Pacific (accept inhabitation, discovery, exploration, wayfinding, or similar words in place of “settlement”; accept Melanesia, Micronesia, or Polynesia in place of “Pacific”; prompt on just “exploration”, “navigation”, or “wayfinding” with “Of where?”; do not accept answers about non-Austronesian settlement of the region)

tossups.question: Descriptive answer acceptable  Condottiero Filippo Strozzi led a French force that joined an unsuccessful attempt to prevent this political period. Margaret of Savoy, Duchess of Mantua was captured by the Forty Conspirators in their effort to end this political period. The shift in foreign policy caused by this political period allowed for the brief Dutch control of northeastern Brazil. The city of Ceuta was officially transferred as part of the treaty ending the war immediately following this political period. His defeat at the Battle of Alcântara ended (*) António, Prior of Crato’s attempt to prevent this political period. This political period resulted from the accession of the celibate Henry the Cardinal-King after the death at the Battle of Alcácer Quibir of Sebastian I, the last king of the Aviz Dynasty. For 10 points, what was this political period lasting from 1580-1640 when a peninsula in southwestern Europe was ruled by a single monarch?
tossups.answer: Iberian Union (accept descriptive answers that suggest that Spain and Portugal are politically unified; prompt on “Portuguese succession crisis” or “War of Protuguese Succession” with “What was the result?”)

tossups.question: A song supposedly composed by a man who fought the expansion of this empire was adapted and secretly passed down through the Chabad Rebbes until it was made public in 1958. Resistance fighters attempted to prevent the construction of a fort by this empire on the Sunzha River, but were mowed down as they tried to capture a cannon left in the open as bait. The fortified village, or aul [ah-OOL], of Gimry was a base for fighting against this empire during the Murid War. Most of the people living in the Kuban River basin were killed or deported by the forces of this empire seeking its pastureland. The Caucasian (*) Imamate formed to wage a holy war against this empire as it sought to join Georgia with the rest of its territory. The life of a warrior who fought both for and against this empire was fictionalized in the novella Hadji Murat. For 10 points, what is this empire whose holdings in the Caucasus were recreated by its successor, the Soviet Union?

This leader lost one position after a vote of no confidence engineered by the monarchist Victor de Broglie. While Minister of the Interior, this leader helped put down a legitimist uprising by the Duchesse de Berry. This leader founded the liberal newspaper Le National, and as prime minister, he initiated a set of sloped walls whose boundaries still demarcate the city of Paris today. As a historian, this leader published a major history of the (*) French Revolution in 1827, which praised the Revolution of 1789 but criticized the Reign of Terror. Buildings like the Tuileries palace and the Hotel de Ville were burned after this first president of the French Third Republic ordered an assault led by Patrice McMahon. For 10 points, name this French leader who ordered the suppression of the Paris Commune during the “Bloody Week”.

A traveler from this modern country reported that after being granted guardianship of the Lighthouse of Alexandria, a foreigner had stolen its mirror and thrown it into the sea. A history written in this modern country describes the “flying bridge” built over the Euphrates at the Roman city of Zeugma. An unknown Roman in this modern country is believed to have first introduced the practice of changing “flints into crystal by means of fire”, otherwise known as glassblowing. An emissary from this modern country to Rome wrote of Roman sea (*) silk, despite never entering Roman territory, due to the machinations of Parthian officials. One man’s return to this modern country after being captured at the Battle of Talas was recorded in the now mostly lost Jīngxíngjì [cheeng-sheeng-jee]. For 10 points, what is this modern country, the home of such travelers as Gān Yīng and Fǎ Xiǎn [shyen]?
tossups.answer: People’s Republic of China (accept Zhōngguó or PRC)

tossups.question: One organization criticized Stanley Gortikov, an executive in this industry, for only providing one blanket response in line with their goals instead of a series of specialized ones. An argument leveled against this industry was revealed to be a misinterpretation of a text about throat surgery undergone by Eddie Ojeda (oh-JAY-duh). A man working in this industry claimed that the political and media attention over one controversy was the result of “a couple of blowjobs here and there”. This industry was attacked for the alleged practice of (*) “backward masking”. Three representatives of this industry defended it against an organization largely composed of politicians’ wives in a 1985 Senate hearing over adult references in their work. Tipper Gore and the PMRC sought to regulate, for 10 points, what industry, which eventually adopted the Parental Advisory sticker to warn of explicit content?

A Jethro Tull song named after this object repeats the line “So come all you lovers of the good life” and begins by describing an “Old woman with a barrow; life near ending.” One character complains about another character named after this object for “hanging oil lamps next to hardwood paneling” and finding a jockstrap on the floor. The name of this object is a cheat in Age of Empires that turns Juggernaughts into amphibious units. Homer Simpson sues a restaurant whose name is a parody of this object for not giving him (*) “all he could eat” as advertised. A character named after this object refuses to eat without his “dining sock.” After being found bound to a cannon on the seafloor, Bootstrap Bill serves under Davy Jones on this ship in the Pirates of the Caribbean series. For 10 points, name this ghost ship of European legend.

Ōuyáng Xún’s [shoon] calligraphy for one type of these objects was an important model for these objects in Vietnam until the 1940’s. A predecessor to these objects was modeled after a triangle-like musical instrument. The state of Chǔ produced a type of these objects now known as “ant-nosed”. Though their provenance is uncertain, a simplistic style of these objects has been attributed to the reign of Dǒng Zhuó, who supposedly melted nine statues from the Qín Dynasty to make them. Many types of these objects were strung together in groups of 100 through the (*) holes in their centers. Jiāozǐ [chyow-tsuh] emerged during the Sòng Dynasty and served a similar role to these objects. These objects took the place of bronze knife- and spade-shaped objects as media of exchange. For 10 points, identify these metallic objects that today come in denominations of yuán.

John Hunter is believed to have paid £500 for a “giant” one of these objects from Ireland. Many people who worked with these objects in London operated out the Fortune of War public house. Robert Knox was caricatured as a black-furred monster for working with these objects. A group best known for working with these objects first did so to recoup back rent owed by a tenant named Donald. Metal devices called (*) mortsafes were used to protect these objects. A group who sold these objects were found out after attempting to sell to Guy’s Hospital in London for medical training. Most famously traded in Edinburgh by Burke and Hare, for 10 points, identify these objects, which were illegally supplied through grave robbing or murder.
tossups.answer: dead bodies (accept synonyms like corpse or cadaver; prompt on “humans” or synonyms)

tossups.question: This man’s conquest of Chitradurga was delayed by a woman named Obavva, who killed most of a force infiltrating the city by beating them over the head with a large pestle as they exited a hole in the city wall single-file. On the death of a de jure ruler of his realm, this man supposedly watched the royal children playing, selecting the one who played with a jeweled dagger as the successor. This man fired one of his commanders for blinding the Sultan of the Maldives after conquering the islands. This man lost the battles of Porto Novo and Sholinghur to Sir (*) Eyre Coote, eventually leading to the Treaty of Mangalore with the British East India Company. This man’s victory at the Battle of Pollilur included significant use of iron-tubed rockets. For 10 points, identify this de facto ruler of Mysore and father of Tipu Sultan.
